column8: two men were traveling in a car. As they approached a bridge
column9: they saw what appeared to be a flattened out
column10: egg-shaped object hovering approximately 100-150 feet from the top of the bridge.Slowing their vehicle to get a better look
column11: they approached to about 75 foot from the bridge. Suddenly
column12: their car went completely dead. The two men stated that it was like they just cut the key off.  Nothing electrical worked. The driver attempted to restart the engine
column13: but to no avail.The object and the malfunction of their vehicle frightened the men to the point that they hid behind their car. They were able to closely watch the UFO for 30-45 seconds. All at once
column14: the object flashed a white light
column15: causing the two witnesses to feel heat on their faces. The flash was accompanied by a loud sound
column16: like thunder.The UFO now began to slowly rise straight up. It was extremely bright as it did
column17: causing the edge of the object to be fuzzy. Within 5-10 seconds the object was out of sight. The men were then able to restart their car
column18: and rush to the nearest phone to report their sighting. The Ground Observor Corp was contacted first
column19: but did not respond. The men then talked to the Towson Police Department
column20: which sent two patrolmen to the scene.The two men soon began to experience a burning sensation on their skin
column21: and went to St. Joseph's Hospital in Baltimore for treatment. They were examined
column22: and each man returned to his own home.Follow-up investigation would reveal some more details of the incident. The bridge was double-arched
column24: and 500 feet long. The distance from the witnesses to the object was estimated at about 3/4 of a mile. Also
column25: there was no unusual atmospheric conditions at the time
column26: and the skies were clear.Project Blue Book investigated the case
column27: but found no absolute cause for the appearance of the object. The case remains unidentified
column28: although the Air Force did state that the object constituted no security threat to the United States.The two witnesses would subsequently be identified as Phillip Small and Alvin Cohen.B J Boothsource and references:Project Blue Bookwww.nicap.org'

column39: The Monon Railroad UFO Incident (Indiana)A Monon railroad train crew reported seeing a UFO in north central Indiana. It was about 3.20 A.M. on Friday October 3
column40: 1958... freight train no. 91 was enroute southbound from Monon
column41: to Indianapolis. In the cab of the diesel locomotive were three men - Harry Eckman
column50: were in the caboose. Cecil Bridge
column52: a former air force man with 450 hours of heavy bomber time
column53: begins the story as follows... '... we had just pulled past a little spot called Owasco. There\'s no town there - just a kind of crossroads. It was there we first noticed four lights in the sky ahead of us. They were moving lights. 'About that time the lights veered west. They crossed the tracks ahead of the train - about a half a mile ahead of us
column54: we estimated. They were moving pretty slowly
column56: at no more than about 50 miles an hour
column59: soft lights.''Just the three of us in the engine saw the lights at this time. We were pulling 56 cars - that\'s a little more than half a mile of cars - and because of the angle at which these things were approaching and because they were so low right then
column60: the boys in the caboose probably couldn\'t see them.''...I talked to Robinson
column62: and told him what we had seen. During the time we watched these things
column64: we did a lot of talking on that radio. The dispatcher in Lafayette could hear us
column66: but he never cut in. Conductor Robinson continues the story. 'I was sitting in the cupola
column68: when Bridge called me on the radio. I had already noticed the four gobs of light but I couldn\'t make out what they were. They were half a mile ahead of the caboose - the whole length of the train. A little bit after he called me the things went away and we didn\'t see them for a few minutes... then all of a sudden they came back.''I\'d say they were only a couple of hundred feet above the train as they came toward the caboose. And they weren\'t moving very fast - maybe 30 or 40 miles an hour. It was hard to tell - a fellow just doesn\'t notice details like that under the circumstances.''The freight train is pretty noisy
column70: but I didn\'t hear any other noise
column71: like the roar an airplane would have made. I think they were silent
column73: at least.''They flew over us one after the other - big
column74: round white things that looked about the colour of fluorescent lights
column75: kind of fuzzy around the edges. They didn\'t glare and they didn\'t light up things as they went over. They just came back toward us
column76: over the top of the cars
column77: one after the other. Then they went on down the tracks maybe another half a mile and seemed to stop.''Sosbey and I went out on the back platform where we could see them better
column78: but they were getting pretty far behind us. We could see their lights but I don\'t remember whether they were bunched up or not. They were just there
column79: we know that. We could see them behind us
column81: observing the same objects from the engine
column82: describes what he and the engineer and head brakeman saw. 'When these things shot back over to the east of us
column83: they lit up much brighter than they were before. They turned in line
column84: going north or northeast and we noticed that they lit up in sequence - the front one first
column86: three and four. They changed course and came back past the train. They were going in the opposite direction to us when they made this pass. I guess they were at least a mile or two east of us when they did it.'The conductor
column88: agreed with this description. He added: 'We didn\'t see them from the back end of the train for several minutes after they went away to the east and turned. But the boys in the engine were still seeing them. I got back on the radio with Bridge. He was watching them right then. They must have circled the train and gone north of us
column90: because the next time we saw them they came rushing up the tracks right in back of us. They were coming a lot faster this time - a lot faster than they had come back over the train the first time.'They were just above the tree-tops along the right of way
column91: and they had changed their way of flying -- their formation. This time they were sort of flying on edge. Two of them were on edge - the two in the middle. The two on the outside were tilted at an angle both in the same direction. The four of them flew like that up the tracks behind the train - a tilted one on the east
column92: two of them straight up and down
column93: then the one on the west tilted just like the one on the east.'When they first came back over the train we could see that they were round things - circular shaped on the bottom. Then when they flew up the tracks in back of us we could see - Sosbey and I - that they were about 40 feet in diameter and maybe 10 feet thick. The two flying straight up and down were approximately over the edges of the right of way and about 200 yards in back of the caboose. If they had been flying flat down instead of edgewise. They would have just about have touched edges so they must have seen somewhere around 40 feet across the bottom.'Fireman Cecil Bridge continues: 'We had flashlights in the engine and in the caboose. Up on the head end of the train - in the engine where I was --we blinked our flashlights at the things and we waved the lights. We thought we might get them to come in closer. They did come down over the train a few minutes later
column96: I can\'t say they did it because we flashed the lights at them. At any rate they didn\'t flash any lights back at us.''In the caboose we had a five cell sealed beam flashlight that throws a pretty good beam a long ways. When the things came down and flew right up the tracks behind the caboose
column97: I grabbed that sealed beam flashlight and shined it on them. As soon as the light hit them they jumped sideways out of the beam. When they got back over the tracks I did it it again and they scattered. They acted like they didn\'t care for that light at all.'From the time Bridge first called us on the radio until the last time we saw them near Kirklin (38 miles northwest of Indianapolis) it was about an hour and 10 minutes altogether. They hung around the back end of the train but after we shined the light on them they didn\'t come in close any more. While we were switching at Frankfort they stayed away back up the tracks
column99: until we moved on. Then they followed us again. When they finally went away at Kirklin
column100: they just zipped off to the northeast and kept on going and we didn\'t see them anymore.' written by Frank Edwards'
column101: 'The Trinidade Island Photographs 1958Trinidade Island UFO PhotographTrindade is a small
column103: rocky island located in the middle of the South Atlantic Ocean
column104: between the Brazilian coast and the African continent
column105: more than six hundred miles off the coast of Bahia.During World War II
column106: it was used as a military base for United States and Brazilian warships engaging German U-boats.It was abandoned after the end of the war
column107: remaining completely deserted and forgotten until 1957.In October of that year a task force from the Brazilian Navy arrived there
column108: under the command of Captain-of-Corvette Carlos Alberto Bacellar.The Hydrography and Navigation Division of the Ministry of the Navy had decided to build an oceanographic post and a meteorological station on the island for research connected with the International Geophysical Year (IGY).In early January 1958 the ship 'Almirante Saldanha' left Rio de Janeiro\'s harbor and proceeded toward the Island of Trindade with a crew of three hundred. The ship had previously been a Brazilian Navy training vessel
column109: but it had been converted into a hydrographic unit to be used for IGY-related research.It was operated by the Hydrography and Navigation Division
column112: it had made several trips to Trindade
column113: most of them connected with the Navy\'s oceanographic studies for the IGY.Several civilians were aboard the ship this time
column114: officially invited to collaborate in the scientific studies which were underway at the island.One of these men was Almiro Barauna
column115: a photographer and former newspaperman working as a 'free-lancer.' He was also an expert in submarine photography.After a routine trip
column116: the ship arrived at the Island and stayed there for several days. It was scheduled to leave for Rio on January 16. On that day
column118: when the ship was preparing to depart
column119: a strange object was sighted simultaneously by a number of observers gathered on deck.The UFO came toward the island at high speed
column121: disappeared behind it for a short time
column122: and appeared again to move away toward the sea.Mr. Barauna was taking pictures of the ship\'s maneuvers at that moment. He spotted the UFO and got four pictures of it.Barauna was later interviewed by reporter Joao Martins and his statements were published in the Brazilian magazine '0 Cruzeiro' in the March 8
column123: 1958 issue. Here is a translation of that interview:Q. Mr. Barauna
column124: what were the reasons for your presence aboard the NE Almirante Saldanha?A. The Navy had invited several teams specialized in submarine hunting to visit the Island of Trindade. I am a member of the Icarai Club for Submarine Hunting
column125: and our group was invited for the last trip. So
column128: I was aboard together with the following members of my group:Amilar Yieira Filho
column130: a government employee (he has a job at the CACEX); Jose Teobaldo Viegas
column131: instructor at the Aero Club of Niteroi and Air Force captain (retired); Mauro Andrade
column132: from the London Bank; and Aloisio
column133: municipal employee at the Federal District.We were going to try to beat some records on submarine hunting.Personally
column134: I was going to take underwater photographs for the Navy and
column136: to write some articles about the Island and the activities of the scientists working for the IGY.Q. Were any other civilians aboard
column137: besides your group?A. Yes. There was Professor Fernando
column141: and a reporter from the newspaper Jornal do Brasil. The three scientists left the ship and went to the island.'Q. Please tell me what was the date of the sighting? What happened?A. It was on January 16
column142: at 12:15 P.M. The ship was preparing to leave the island
column143: to come back to Rio. I was on the deck observing the operations to take aboard the boat used in the trips between the ship and the island (the island has no harbor).The sea was agitated. The weather was cloudy
column145: with no shadows. I had my Rolleiflex 2.8
column147: which was kept inside an aluminum box for protection against the corrosive effects of water and salt. I had left my Leica with a telephoto lens in my cabin a few moments before. The deck was full of sailors and officers. Suddenly
column148: Mr. Amilar Vieira and Captain Viegas called me
column149: pointing to a certain spot in the sky and yelling about a bright object which was approaching the island.At this same moment
column150: when I was still trying to see what it was
column153: came from the bow toward us
column155: pointing out to the sky and also yelling about an object he was sighting. He was so disturbed and excited that he almost fell down after colliding with a cable. Then I was finally able to locate the object
column156: by the flash (of light) it emitted.It was already close to the island. It glittered at certain moments
column157: perhaps changing its own light - I don\'t know. It was coming over the sea
column158: moving toward the point called the Galo Crest. I had lost thirty seconds looking for the object
column159: but the camera was already in my hands
column161: when I sighted it clearly silhouetted against the clouds.I shot two photos before it disappeared behind the peak Desejado. My camera was set at a speed of 125 [125th of a second
column163: and this was the cause of an overexposure error
column164: as I discovered later.'The object remained out of sight for a few seconds - behind the peak - reappearing bigger in size and flying in the opposite direction
column165: but lower and closer than before
column166: and moving at a higher speed. I shot the third photo. The fourth and fifth ones were lost
column167: not only because of the speed the saucer was moving
column168: but also for another reason:In the confusion produced as a result of the sighting
column169: I was being pulled and pushed by other persons also trying to spot the object and
column171: photographed the sea and the island only - not the object. It was moving out to sea again
column172: in the direction from which it had come
column173: and it appeared to stop in midair for a brief time. At that moment I shot my last photo (the last on the film).After about ten seconds
column174: the object continued to increase its distance from the ship
column175: gradually diminishing in size and finally disappearing into the horizon.Q. Did you hear anything unusual during the sighting? Was the object emitting any sound?A. I am not sure
column177: because of the noise made by the sea waves against the island\'s rocks
column178: as well as for the yelling aboard the ship at the time. However
column179: I think that I heard nothing besides those sounds.Q. What was the color of the object?A. It showed a dark gray color
column180: appearing to be surrounded - mostly in the area ahead of it - by a kind of condensation of a greenish
column181: phosphorescent vapor (or mist).Q. Did the object appear to be metallic?A. Yes. It was obviously a solid object.Q. How was it flying? Any special characteristics?A. Yes. It showed an undulatory movement as it flew across the sky
column182: like the flight of a bat. And when it came back
column185: in a jump.Q. Do you know how many persons aboard the Almirante Saldanha sighted the object?A. The object was sighted by almost all the people on the deck at that time
column188: and Mr. Amilar Vieira.Q. What happened after the sighting?A. The ship\'s commander and several officers from the garrison wanted to see what I had got in the photos. As I was very curious too
column189: I decided to develop the exposed film at once
column190: aboard the ship. The processing was done under the supervision of several officers
column191: including Commander Carlos A. Bacellar. But only the negatives were seen aboard. The reason: There was no photographic paper for the copies on the ship at that time. The negatives
column193: were seen and examined by the whole crew.Q. Did you keep the negatives in your hands?A. Yes.Q. Were you under any pressure to give up those negatives to Naval authorities?(click on image to see full size)A. No. Commander Saldanha da Gama (the ship\'s CO) and the other Navy officers aboard were very kind. They never tried to get the negatives from me.Q. What happened when the ship came back to Rio?A. The ship stopped first at Vitoria
column194: in the State of Espirito Santo. As it was going to stay there for two days and later travel to Rio
column195: we were permitted - the civilians from the submarine-hunting group only - to leave the ship there and to take a bus for the rest of the trip. Later
column196: two days after the arrival of the Almirante Saldanha at Rio
column197: Commander Bacellar (ex-commander of the Navy Post at Trindade) appeared at my residence. He wanted to see the enlargements made from the negatives and asked permission to take them to the Naval authorities.Two days later
column198: they were returned with congratulations. I was also requested to appear at the Navy Ministry as soon as possible. They wanted to ask me certain questions and to see the negatives again.Q. And what happened there?A. I was interviewed by several high-staff officers
column199: who asked me all kinds of questions. I went there twice. At the first meeting
column200: they requested the negatives for examination. They were sent to a civilian organization
column201: the Cruzeiro do Sul Aerophoto grammetric Service
column202: remaining there for four days. I was told by the Navy officers that the analyses proved they were genuine -excluding definitely the possibility of a trick or falsification. On the second visit
column203: they performed several time-tests. While I worked with my Rolleiflex
column204: taking shots at the same time intervals I had used to photograph the object
column205: three Navy officers with chronometers registered the times.They came to the conclusion - based on these tests as well as on studies concerning the ship\'s position and examinations of charts of the island - that the object was flying at a speed between 900 and 1
column206: 000 km./hour [about 600 mph. The object\'s size was also estimated on the basis of studies related with the island\'s details also appearing on the photos
column209: et cetera. The object was about 120 feet in diameter and about 24 feet high.Q. Do you know anything about the official report on the case?A. I saw a dossier which was consulted many times during the interrogation. However
column210: I didn\'t read what was written there. I was also informed that my photos
column212: had been shown to witnesses of the sighting - to be identified. The result was positive.Q. Do you know anything about any photos by other people aboard the ship?A. No. Besides myself
column213: there were at least four other persons with cameras at the time of the sighting. But apparently they were not able to spot the object in time
column214: or were paralyzed by their emotions.Q. Were you warned against something by the Navy\'s authorities? Was there some recommendation?A. Yes. They requested me to keep the matter secret for some time. I was permitted to publish the case only after authorization from the Navy. The permission was granted
column217: by Commander Bacellar. They made only one restriction
column218: which I cannot mention for the reason that I have given my word.Q. Do you know if your sighting was the first over the Island of Trindade?A. I was informed of four other sightings over the island during those thirty days preceding the incident of January 16. I was also informed of another thing: At one of those sightings
column219: the object was photographed by a Navy sergeant.His photo obviously was not released and probably never will be - the reasons are evident. Besides those four sightings
column220: there was also the RADAR case. A target flying at supersonic speed was tracked by the radar of the Almirante Saldanha on January 15.Q. Did you receive any money from the Navy for your work at the Island of Trindade?A. No. I was there as a guest.Q. Did you receive any money from the Navy for your photographic work
column221: or for the enlargements you made for them?A. No. I only received the photographic paper to be used for enlargements.Q. How many enlargements have you given them.A. Thirty-eight.Q. One last question: What kind of impression did you get from observing the flying saucer?A. I am absolutely sure it was a controlled object - either directly or by remote control - but very well operated
column222: in any case. The general impression of people aboard the ship was the same: It had come to make a close observation of the ship.Immediately following the publication of the photographs
column223: the Brazilian Navy refused to make any official statement confirming or denying the incident. However
column224: proofs from the original negatives were sent to the other armed forces and to Brazilian President Kubitschek. According to the press
column225: the narration so impressed Mr. Kubitschek that he became convinced of the veracity of the happening.On February 24
column226: three days after the photos were first published in the press
column227: the Ministry of the Navy finally made the following official statement: 'With reference to the reports appearing in the press that the Navy is opposed to divulge the facts concerning the appearance of a strange object over Trindade Island
column228: this Cabinet declares that such information has no basis.This Ministry has no motive to impede the release of photographs of the referred-to object
column230: who was at Trindade Island at the invitation of the Navy
column231: and in the presence of a large number of the crew of Almirante Saldanha from whose deck the photographs were taken. Clearly
column232: this Ministry will not be able to make any pronouncement concerning the object seen
column233: because the photographs do not constitute sufficient proof for such purpose.'On the morning after the photos of the flying saucer were published in the press (February 22)
column234: the Almirante Saldanha departed Rio to continue its mission in connection with the IGY. Two days later
column236: the ship docked at Santos (February 24) for voyage repairs; this was the first chance that newspapermen had an opportunity to interview officers and men aboard.The U.S. Assistant Naval Attache\' was in Santos at this time
column237: in connection with the visit of U. S. Coast Guard Cutter Westwind
column238: and had an opportunity to visit aboard. The commanding officer
column239: Capitao-de-Mar-e-Guerra (Captain) Jose Santos Saldanha da Gama
column240: had not seen the object and was noncommittal. The executive officer also had not seen it but
column242: had formed the opinion that those on deck had seen it.The captain had reported that his secretary
column248: it was learned that the photographer was accompanied to the dark room by an officer who waited outside the door while Barauna developed the negatives alone. When the Westwind\'s commanding officer paid a visit to the Almirante Saldanha
column249: Captain Saldanha da Gama freely discussed the flying saucer incident and showed the original proofs to the callers
column250: but again did not commit himself.Federal Deputy Sergio Magalhaes sent a note to the Ministry of the Navy on February 27
column251: protesting the Navy\'s failure to secure sworn statements from witnesses. 'For the first time in flying saucer history
column252: the phenomenon was attended by large numbers of persons belonging to a military force
column253: which gives these photographs an official stamp.Threats to national security require greater official attention and action
column254: ' said the deputy. In the middle of all the publicity
column255: other sighting reports came to light
column256: including one by a naval officer who saw a UFO a month before the sighting from the Almirante Saldanha
column257: off the coast of Espirito Santo. The commanding officer and crew of the Ata Tridente had seen a UFO several days before the Saldanha episode
column258: but had kept the in formation secret.Source: Ronald Story\'s
